text:
(1)
Coney Island Beach, looking south from Seaside Park, between Ocean Parkway and West 5th Street, showing the Coney Island Boardwalk, under construction.

June 3, 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
The same, looking eastward, showing Parkway Baths in the center of view.

August 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3)
The same, showing at the left, the remains of the Brighton Beach Hotel.

August 1924.

(4)
The same, looking northeast from about West 5th Street. Seaside Park is in the background.

August 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Seaside Park.]

text:
(1)
Coney Island (Reigelmann)Boardwalk, east of theConey Island Pier.
December 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
A view northward from a point furthereast, showing Stubbman's Pavillion (center)and the Prospect Hotel. This hotel, formerly Cables, became known as Doyle's Hotel , after the dome was removed.
December 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3)
The same, further east, showing the "Shelter House", and the Municipal Baths.
December 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(4)
The same, east of Stillwell Ave., showing the Cox and Ocean Baths in the foreground.
April 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Riegelmann boardwalk - Coney Island pier.]

text:
(1)
Coney Island, Boardwalk, north side, west of Stillwell Ave.
December 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
The same, looking north from the Coney Island Beach, west of view one, between West 19th and 15th Streets.
March 31, 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3)
The same, a close-up, showing Noah's Ark in Steeplechase Park.
December 31, 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(4)
The same, a later view of No. 1.
September 1926.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

text:
Coney Island Beach, with boardwalk and amusement park in the background.  Note the great variety shown in bathing suits.
About 1925

Ewing Galloway
Neg. #1822 (8x10 neg)
title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Riegelmann boardwalk.]

text:
Coney Island's beach and boardwalk seen from the Atlantic. At the left is the new Half-Moon Hotel.
About 1928.
Ewing Galloway.
title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Half-Moon Hotel.]

text:
(1)
A general view of the beach, showing the dense throng of bathers and sunbathers. In the distance is the Half-Moon Hotel.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A good view of a Coney Island crowd. Oddly enough, this is a week-day crowd. It is difficult to attempt to picture the scene on a weekend.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A supurb marine photograph, which gives a good idea of the terrific mob at Coney Island Beach. In the background, sharply silhouetted against the sky, is the Half-Moon Hotel.
August 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Half-Moon Hotel.]

text:
(1)
Sunbathers on Coney Island Beach.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A general view of the beach and the crowd of sunbathers.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
An extremely dense portion of the beach, showing the ocean and, dimly in the distance, a small sailing vessel.
August 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Sunbathers.]

title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Sunbathers.]

text:
(1)
Sunbathers at Coney Island Beach who, with clothes on hickory limb, are not going near the water.
August 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A small portion of the beach. Notice the flower vendor peddling his wares. As this is a week-day, the crowd is not very large.
August 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
More sun-bathers. The pretzel vendor is trying to create a demand for her wares. The pretzels will, of course, create a thirst which can be quenched with lemonade (beer is not yet legal), the lemonade and sea-air will cause a hunger to be satisfied with hot-dogs, hamburger and onions, and ice-cream, which will cause a stomachache to be subdued with bicarbonate of soda.
August 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Sunbathers and vendors.]

text:

Water-Babies, and a portion of the Coney Island Beach.
August 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
Sun-bathers, the ocean, and, in the distance, A small sailingboat.
August 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A close view of the beach, bathers, and a bathing pier.
July 8, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

text:
(1) Coney Island Beach and the Atlantic Ocean on a still day, showing swimmers and sunbathers.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

(2) Beach and pier from the boardwalk.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

(3) Portion of beach. Even though this is a weekday, note the density of the crowd. On a hot Saturday, Sunday or holiday, there is not an unoccupied square inch on the entire beach.
August 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Islands - Coney Island beach - The Atlantic Ocean - [Swimmers and sunbathers.]

text:
(1)
Coney Island Beach and a pavillion. At the right is a lifeguard's stand, and in the background is a bathing pier.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
Beach and sunbathers. An ice-cream peddler does his bit to
boost the sale of bicarbonate of soda.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A general view of the beach, showing piers and the ocean at the right, and a portion of the boardwalk at the left.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Islands - Coney Island beach - Coney Island Pavilion.

text:
(1)
An excellent action photograph of a man being tossed from a blanket, Coney Island Beach.
July 4, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
Another victim goes aloft -- this time a girl.
July 4, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A second girl points her toes skyward.
July 4, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Sunbathers.]

text:
(1)
A holiday crowd at Coney Island Beach. In the centre someone
is being tossed from a blanket.
July 4, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
Beach, ocean, and piers at Coney Island. Although this picture was made on a Saturday, the crowd is not very dense. Later in the summer, as the days get hotter, it will be difficult to see the beach at all, for the crowds.
July 8, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
Beach, swimmers, and sunbathers at Coney Island.
July 8, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Sunbathers and swimmers.]

text:
(1)
A view of the Beach, When approximately a million people congregate to enjoy themselves. In the background, is the Reigelmann (Coney Island) Boardwalk. At the left, is the 14-story Half-Moon Hotel, on the north side of the boardwalk, between 29th and 28th Streets.
July 4, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A continuation of No. 1, (Coney Island).
July 4, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
Another view of Plate No. 1. (Coney Island).
July 4, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Half-Moon Hotel - Riegelmann boardwalk.]

text:
(1) Coney Island Beach, viewed northeastward from the water, showing on the shore line Coney Island's Half Moon Hotel.
August 30, 1936.
P.L. Sperr

(2) The same, showing a further view west.
September 6, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, still further west showing at the left Seagate's private water front.
September 6, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

text:
Coney Island: showing three views of the bathing beach upon which it has been estimated as many as one million bathers have enjoyed themselves at one time. View No. 2 shows the S.S. Hook Mountain approaching the pier at Coney Island.
July 2, 1938.
Views 1,2 and 3.
P. L. Sperr
title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Coney Island pier.]

text:
Coney Island: showing three views of the bathing beach upon which it has been estimated as many as one million bathers have enjoyed themselves at one time. View No. 2 shows the S.S. Hook Mountain approaching the pier at Coney Island.
July 2, 1938.
Views 1,2 and 3.
P. L. Sperr
